paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Lab:** Sqoop to HDFS
**Objective:** Collect data from the RDBMS with Sqoop scripts. Store into HDFS and load into Hive
**File locations:** Cloudair DB in PostgreSQL
**Successful outcome:** Collect data with Sqoop
**Before you begin:** Cloudair DB is in PostgreSQL
**Related lessons:** Sqoop in Action, Recommend Practice for SLA for Raw Data Retention

---

msg.data:
About

Lab: Sqoop to HDFS
Objective: Collect data from the RDBMS with Sqoop scripts. Store into HDFS and load into Hive
File locations: Cloudair DB in PostgreSQL
Successful outcome: Collect data with Sqoop
Before you begin: Cloudair DB is in PostgreSQL
Related lessons: Sqoop in Action, Recommend Practice for SLA for Raw Data Retention

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup

msg.data: Setup

paragraphs.title: Ensure cloudair database is running in PostgreSQL
paragraphs.text:
%sh
export PGPASSWORD='BadPass%1'; psql -h db01.cloudair.lan -U devuser -d cloudair -p 5432  <<EOF
\dt
EOF

paragraphs.title: Delete HDFS /data/cloudair
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair

paragraphs.title: Drop cloudair Hive Database
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP DATABASE IF EXISTS cloudair CASCADE;

%md
# Lab

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Create Hive database

msg.data: Create Hive database

paragraphs.title: 1 - Create cloudair Hive database

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to import the eu_country table

msg.data: Use Sqoop to import the eu_country table

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create table eu_country_stage
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.eu_country_stage;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.eu_country_stage(
  country_name STRING,
  country_code STRING,
  region STRING
  )
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED 
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION '/data/cloudair/eu_country';

paragraphs.title: 3 - Sqoop import table eu_country into a raw directory
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/eu_country
rm /home/zeppelin/eu_country.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--table eu_country \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/eu_country \
--num-mappers 1

%md
#### **Important** 
Ignore the warning about Accumulo, the code is not installed.

You may get a message that the "Paragraph received a SIGTERM". If the paragraph status in the top right corner is "FINISHED" and not "ERROR" that indicates the job completed successfully; you can also run the next paragraph to confirm that the result is in the /data/cloudair/eu_country directory.

If the job did not complete successfully, it may have failed due to a lack of available memory. In this case, run the paragraph again.

msg.data:
Important

Ignore the warning about Accumulo, the code is not installed.

You may get a message that the “Paragraph received a SIGTERM”. If the paragraph status in the top right corner is “FINISHED” and not “ERROR” that indicates the job completed successfully; you can also run the next paragraph to confirm that the result is in the /data/cloudair/eu_country directory.

If the job did not complete successfully, it may have failed due to a lack of available memory. In this case, run the paragraph again.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir The HDFS directory to land the files. Scoop will create the directory and load the files.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

~~~

msg.data:
Defining the Sqoop options

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir The HDFS directory to land the files. Scoop will create the directory and load the files.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

paragraphs.title: 4 - Check raw data in HDFS /data/cloudair/eu_country
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls /data/cloudair/eu_country

%md
The data file is now a MapReduce partition file. However, this will not affect the way Hive loads the data.

msg.data: The data file is now a MapReduce partition file. However, this will not affect the way Hive loads the data.

paragraphs.title: 5 - Display the data from the partition file
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -cat /data/cloudair/eu_country/part-m-00000

%md
Sqoop imports the data from an RDBMS table as .csv format

msg.data: Sqoop imports the data from an RDBMS table as .csv format

paragraphs.title: 6 - Create managed table eu_country as ORC format
7 - Use an ITAS statement to load data into eu_country
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
INSERT INTO cloudair.eu_country SELECT * FROM cloudair.eu_country_stage;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 8 - Run query on eu_country
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
SELECT * FROM cloudair.eu_country LIMIT 5;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

[{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 9 - Drop the table
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.eu_country;

paragraphs.title: 10 - Use HDFS to check datasets
paragraphs.text:
%sh
hdfs dfs -ls -R /data/cloudair

%md
The raw data is still located in /data/cloudair/eu_country.  This will require the use of the hdfs dfs -rm command to remove the data.

msg.data: The raw data is still located in /data/cloudair/eu_country. This will require the use of the hdfs dfs -rm command to remove the data.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to import the sale table

msg.data: Use Sqoop to import the sale table

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create table sale_stage
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.sales_stage;

CREATE TEMPORARY EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.sale_stage(
    `entry_date` DATE,
    `item` STRING,
    `sales_code` INT,
    `cc_type` STRING,
    `first_name` STRING,
    `last_name` STRING,
    `city` STRING,
    `country_name` STRING,
    `purchase_date` DATE,
    `delivery_date` DATE,
    `purchase` DECIMAL(10,2),
    `credits` DECIMAL(10,2)
    )
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED 
FIELDS TERMINATED BY ','
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION '/data/cloudair/sale';

paragraphs.title: 12 - Sqoop import table sale by columns
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/sale
rm /home/zeppelin/sale.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--table sale \
--columns "entry_date,item,first_name,last_name,city,country_name" \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/sale \
--num-mappers 1

%md
#### **Important**
If you do not adjust the create statement for the Hive table the HDFS dataset will not be in alignment with the Hive table. Data will be misaligned into the wrong columns.

msg.data:
Important

If you do not adjust the create statement for the Hive table the HDFS dataset will not be in alignment with the Hive table. Data will be misaligned into the wrong columns.

paragraphs.text:
%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
columns - The selected columns from the RDBMS DB table
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

~~~

Defining the Sqoop options

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
columns - The selected columns from the RDBMS DB table
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

paragraphs.title: 13 - Create managed table sale as ORC format
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.sale;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.sale(
    `entry_date` DATE,
    `item` STRING,
    `sales_code` INT,
    `cc_type` STRING,
    `first_name` STRING,
    `last_name` STRING,
    `city` STRING,
    `country_name` STRING,
    `purchase_date` DATE,
    `delivery_date` DATE,
    `purchase` DECIMAL(10,2),
    `credits` DECIMAL(10,2)
    )
COMMENT 'Cloudair Sales'
STORED AS ORC;

paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
INSERT INTO cloudair.sale SELECT * FROM cloudair.sale;

paragraphs.text:
%md
The data file is not aligned with the schema. This is a common occurence in moving data through the platform. 
It is a Data Engineering responsibilty to track the impact of changes through the entire system.

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to import us_customer

msg.data: Use Sqoop to import us_customer

paragraphs.title: 16 - Sqoop import table us_customer by rows
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/us_customer
rm /home/zeppelin/us_customer.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--table us_customer \
--where "gender = 'female'" \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/us_customer \
--num-mappers 1

%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
where - The selected rows using a WHERE clause from the RDBMS DB table
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

~~~

msg.data:
Defining the Sqoop options

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
where - The selected rows using a WHERE clause from the RDBMS DB table
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

paragraphs.title: 17 - Create table us_customer_stage
paragraphs.text:
%jdbc(hive_interactive)
DROP TABLE IF EXISTS cloudair.us_customer_stage;

CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE cloudair.us_customer_stage(
    row_id STRING,
    title STRING,
    first_name STRING,
    middle_initial STRING,
    last_name STRING,
    name_set STRING,
    street_address STRING,
    city STRING,
    state STRING,
    state_name STRING,
    zip_code INT,
    country_id STRING,
    country_name STRING,
    telephone_country_code STRING,
    telephone_number STRING,
    email_address STRING,
    username STRING,
    password STRING,
    national_id STRING,
    mrn INT,
    insurance_id INT,
    cc_type STRING,
    cc_number STRING,
    cvv2 INT,
    cc_expires DATE,
    occupation STRING,
    company STRING,
    domain STRING,
    vehicle STRING,
    gender STRING,
    mothers_maiden STRING,
    birthday DATE,
    tropical_zodiac STRING,
    age INT,
    eye_color STRING,
    blood_type STRING,
    weight DOUBLE,
    height INT,
    latitude DOUBLE,
    longitude DOUBLE
    )
ROW FORMAT DELIMITED FIELDS 
TERMINATED BY ',' ESCAPED BY '"'
STORED AS TEXTFILE
LOCATION '/data/cloudair/us_customer'
tblproperties("skip.header.line.count"="1");

paragraphs.text:
%md
#### Use Sqoop to import ww_customer

msg.data: Use Sqoop to import ww_customer

paragraphs.title: 21 - Sqoop import table ww_customer by query
paragraphs.text:
%sh
sudo -u hdfs hdfs dfs -rm -r -skipTrash /data/cloudair/ww_customer
rm /home/zeppelin/ww_customer.java

sqoop import \
--connect jdbc:postgresql://db01.cloudair.lan:5432/cloudair \
--username devuser \
--password BadPass%1 \
--query "SELECT first_name, last_name, street_address, city, state_code, country_code FROM ww_customer WHERE \$CONDITIONS AND gender = 'male'" \
--target-dir /data/cloudair/ww_customer \
--num-mappers 1

%md
#### **Important**
The syntax for --query requires the use of $CONDITIONS to access metadata from the DB table to provide information about the columns. If you use double quotes around the query statement you must backslash, \\\$CONDITIONS

msg.data:
Important

The syntax for –query requires the use of $CONDITIONS to access metadata from the DB table to provide information about the columns. If you use double quotes around the query statement you must backslash, \\$CONDITIONS

paragraphs.text:
%md
Defining the Sqoop options

~~~console

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
query - Run a complex query against the RDBMS DB, this can include joins and complex where clauses.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

~~~

Defining the Sqoop options

connect - Provides jdbc string
username - Database username
password - Alternatively you can use -password but this is not a good practice as it is visible in your job execution logs 
           and asking for trouble. One way to deal with this is store database passwords in a file in HDFS and provide 
           at runtime. There is also a -P option to ask for the password from the CLI
table - Tells the computer which table you want to import from MySQL. Here, it is customer.
target-dir - HDFS destination directory.
query - Run a complex query against the RDBMS DB, this can include joins and complex where clauses.
num-mappers - the number of mappers to use during the data transfer

%md

If you do not adjust the create statement for the Hive table the HDFS dataset will not be in alignment with the Hive table. Data will be misaligned in the wrong columns.

paragraphs.title: 21 - Sqoop import table ww_customer by query

%md
#### **Important**
The syntax for --query requires the use of $CONDITIONS to access metadata from teh DB table to provide information about the columns. If you use double quotes around the query statement you must backslash, \\\$CONDITIONS
